record.text: Today, Section 230 continues to be central to debates about AI, competition policy, & platform liability. CDT’s work spans amicus briefs, legal analyses, and policy guidance — all focused on ensuring courts and Congress protect free expression, innovation, and diverse online communities.

Section 230 is fundamentally a protection for users. It lets people share information without platforms pre-screening every post, and it ensures services can moderate spam, abuse, and harassment — essential for keeping marginalized voices from being pushed out of online spaces.

Section 230 turns 30 this week — and the stakes for online free expression have never been higher. As some lawmakers move to restrict speech, 230 remains a  safeguard so people can speak and organize without platforms being pressured to shut them down. cdt.org/insights/sec...

images.alt:
Two-page image of a formal letter on U.S. House of Representatives letterhead, dated February 8, 2026, addressed to Chairman James Comer of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee. The letter states that Ghislaine Maxwell plans to invoke her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination at an upcoming House Oversight deposition and criticizes her intent to do so on a blanket basis rather than question by question. It notes her prior meeting with Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche and requests clarity on whether she will invoke the Fifth Amendment in response to specific questions.

Page one lists six detailed questions concerning alleged co-conspirators in Jeffrey Epstein’s abuse of minors, the lack of indictments, Maxwell’s knowledge of prosecutorial decisions, any role involving President Donald Trump, discussions of a potential presidential pardon in exchange for silence, and any client lists or records maintained by Maxwell or Epstein.

Page two adds a seventh question asking Maxwell to identify any foreign governments or intelligence services, including those linked to Russia or Israel, with which Epstein allegedly shared information or acted on behalf of. The letter asks that this document be entered into the official record at the start of the deposition and closes with a formal sign-off and signature from Congressman Ro Khanna, Member of Congress, U.S. House of Representatives.

record.text:
“Black” is being flagged as a potentially prohibited word violating anti-DEI law at multiple Florida Universities. My interview this week with @grundrza.bsky.social documents his event being flagged because the flyer said “Black.”

Racial authoritarianism is here, it’s just unequally distributed.

value.text: FAMU can't use the word Black on anything posted around campus related to Black History Month, to stay in compliance with Florida state laws against DEI. Black students can't use the word Black at their Historically Black College during Black History Month.

record.text: ANYWAY if you work with a progressive group and want to get 'em off IG and build 'em up here on bluesky, reach out and i will try to help if you want help.

also, if you're a progressive group, you should be trying to break the power of billionaires, and part of that involves getting people off of billionaire-owned communication sites. that's not just ethical, it's strategic and practical and political - those sites are working against us.

and i still get served people's posts on IG several days after the events they're plugging already happened. that's trash! it's a garbage website that doesn't serve the actual needs of the groups that are posting there!

the way i pitch it right now is that bluesky lets you reach and organize the organizers. which is absolutely critical! i'm regularly overwhelmed by how many people sign up to DO THINGS when i post about them here.

you can sometimes reach more eyeballs on IG, but you can get folks to DO things here.

yes, many many more people are on IG. but IG doesn't show your posts to most of the people you follow AND it prevents you from posting live links. if you want to organize efficiently and actually reach your followers and get them to DO things, bluesky's tools are VASTLY better.

sadly, i suspect the problem with most progressive groups is that their internet people only have so much time and they haven't been able to take the half day to figure out how to incorporate bluesky into their posting schedules. this is an issue because zuckerberg's IG will eventually cut them off.
Spicy take, but the 20% of the people who don't make it back to a stable life still deserve to have their basic needs met.

embed.alt: Video showing a mutual aid distribution. There are tables set up against a colorfully painted construction fence. Some people are moving in a line down the tables and getting resources and other people are serving them food, sharing groceries, toiletries, information, and folding clothing. Behind the fence the sky is blue. Everyone is dressed warmly. Video text is all in white font with blue outline. Text reads: We The People NYC. Bedstuy & Harlem. Building community through mutual aid for over four years. Every Saturday in Harlem, Lexington ave & 124th st. 1 pm until ~ 2:30 / 3pm. Every Thursday in Bedstuy, Fulton st & Nostrand ave. 1 pm until ~ 2:30 / 3pm. We are neighbors supporting neighbors, sharing hot meals, clothing, groceries, toiletries, and information. In a system built to fail us, we can keep us safe. Strong communities are the first step, where all are fed, clothed, and cared for.

images.alt:
Pioli: Another player that we brought from the Patriots to the Chiefs is Ryan O'Callaghan.
In 2011, he came out to me that he was gay. He didn't come out publicly for another six years.
He had told me, "Scott, I need you to keep this secret." The day that that article came out in Outsports by Cyd Zeigler, I heard from two former players from the Chiefs: Ryan Lilja, one of the offensive linemen, and Mike Vrabel.
Mike said, "Is he OK? Can I please get his contact information? I need to check on him."
Now, everyone sees Mike Vrabel, tough guy.
And he is tough to the death, and he's a man's man and all of that crap. But Mike just wanted to make sure Ryan was OK. That's Mike Vrabel.
